awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Microencapsulation of phase change materials using cenospheres for thermal energy efficiency in building materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of microencapsulated phase change building materials for temperature management and energy efficiency.  Residential and commercial buildings account for about 75% of all electricity use in the US and result in an energy costs that totaled over $410 billion in 2020.  The proposed microcapsule technology may be integrated into building materials to improve US energy efficiency up to 20%.  This reduction in energy use could lead to $82B savings per year.  In addition, the proposed technology may be used in a broad array of building materials including wallboards (e.g., drywall, gypsum boards, acoustical panels, and fire-retardant panels), machine applied plasters, ceiling products, flooring products, dry mortar, cement mixtures, and interior and exterior coatings.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a microencapsulation technology for phase change materials (PCMs) using cenospheres to improve energy efficiency in building materials. In existing technologies, PCMs are microencapsulated by synthesizing a polymer shell on the surface of PCM droplets. This type of shell is expensive and has limited stiffness/strength, low thermal and chemical stability, high flammability, and low thermal conductivity. The proposed technology addresses these problems by using cenopheres as the shell material.  Cenospheres are hollow fly ash particles generated in coal burning power plants. Cenospheres inherently have small pores that are sealed by a thin glass-crystalline film. By removing this film through chemical etching, the pores may be exposed, providing a path for PCMs to enter the internal void of the cenosphere. Once filled, a thin coating is then applied on the PCM-impregnated cenospheres to prevent the possible leaking of liquid PCMs. Compared with existing products, the proposed PCM microcapsules have been shown to be lower cost, stronger, more durable, flame resistant, and higher in thermal conductivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This I-Corps Team Project builds on the PI team's latest patented technology (US Patent 11,142,909) on a novel microcapsule of Phase Change Materials (PCMs), CenoPCM, which uses cenosphere as low-cost, high-strength, fire-resistant shell for the microcapsule.This PCM microcapsule can be widely adopted in various industrials such as building and construction, energy storage, heating, HVAC, shipping and transportation, etc. for energy saving.

The main goal was to conduct customer discovery to explore potential customer segments, learn to develop key elements of a business model, and identify the requirements for the minimum viable products. Throughout the six weeks in the I-Corps program, our team conducted 107 interviews with architects, structural and mechanical engineers, contractors, and suppliers. Eight customer segments have been exploited, among which three were validated.  This customer discovery process not only opened opportunities to understand the needs of the customers, but also helped us to identify the pains and gains of the potential users of thermal energy storage materials. Based on feedbacks collected through the product-market fit validation, a minimum viable product was developed with salt hydrate as the PCM for the proposed CenoPCM microcapsule. This product overcomes the major barrier preventing commercial application of PCM in buildings, high cost. A research partnership between the PI's team and Sutterlin Research, LLC has been established to further refine the product and seek commercialization opportunities.

The training and customer discovery experience gained through the I-Corps program also prepared our team members for future technology translation. The PI won 2022 Faculty/Staff Innovation Pitch of the University of Alabama and successful licensed one of his inventions to a concrete manufacturer. He also guided a group of undergraduate students won the Bama IP Commercialization Academy - the Crimson Startup program, a business plan competition for undergraduate students at the University of Alabama.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/11/2022
Modified by: Jialai Wang
